image.altText: Two brown dogs lie on a road in front of a sign reading Beauty Point Tourist Park.

props.synopsis: Anne owns her cabin and pays fortnightly site fees to the park's management. As a resident of the park, she is not allowed to have overnight guests and is prevented from selling her cabin. She is also not covered by protections in Tasmania's Residential Tenancy Act.

title.children: No overnight guests, no sales of cabins, and eviction fears: Inside the caravan park that sparked a fight for legislative rights

image.altText: Black and white photo of a smiling man patting two wallabies in the bush

props.synopsis: In 1953 Sherpa Tenzing Norgay and Sir Edmund Hillary become the first two people to reach the summit of Mount Everest. Just under 10 years later, Norgay made his mark in another place of wild beauty — Tasmania.

title.children: A Tasmanian boy's 1960s chance meeting with Everest 'legend' Tenzing Norgay

image.altText: An older woman with white hair sits on a seat in their living room.

props.synopsis: Caring for her mother for over 13 years, Beth Jackson gave up a huge chunk of career earnings and superannuation. But advocates say the sacrifices people like Beth make should entitle them to a better deal at the other end.

title.children: 'A nightmare … I really wasn't prepared for how the system doesn't work': The reality of caring for an elderly loved one

image.altText: Kelvin Smith wearing a red puffer jacket and beanie plays an upright piano atop kunanyi/Mount Wellington

props.synopsis: Kelvin Smith is known for playing his piano in picturesque locations around Tasmania. His latest feat, pushing his 240 kilogram instrument to the top of Hobart's kunanyi/Mount Wellington, has been six months in the making.

title.children: Tasmanian man pushes piano up mountain to raise awareness of mental health struggles

image.altText: A macro image of a brown weevil-looking insect clings to the side of a head of fuschia flower bulbs

props.synopsis: Otto and Bruno Bell have always loved the natural world. They have become experts on some of the tiniest snails and weevils, and now a species of weevil is set to be named after them.

title.children: Tasmanian twins double down to help understand some of Australia's tiniest threatened species

image.altText: Exterior shot of an old court building.

props.synopsis: A man who a tribunal heard pushed his ex-wife to the ground while she was on crutches and injured her face with his foot or leg has been barred from re-registering as a psychologist, after his Supreme Court appeal was dismissed.

title.children: Former psychologist who pushed ex-wife on crutches to the ground loses appeal to practise in Tasmania

image.altText: Smoke emerges from the top of a large white and red cruise ship at night with lights reflected in water below.

props.synopsis: The recent TT-Line and TasPorts failures with the Spirit of Tasmania ferry replacement project puts government businesses in the spotlight. Join Airlie Ward and state political reporter Adam Langenberg.

title.children: Listen to TassieCast 🔊 Are Tasmania's government-owned businesses on the line for privatisation?

image.altText: A metal heart-shaped frame is packed with bouquets of flowers and notes.

props.synopsis: The parents and loved ones of the children who died as a result of a jumping castle lifting into the air three years ago have endured two weeks of emotionally charged debate, complex technical discussions and arguing by experts in a Tasmanian court room.

title.children: Did you miss? 📣 Hillcrest jumping castle tragedy court case puts parents, loved ones, through yet another ordeal in search for answers

image.altText: A drone image of Chevron's Gorgon project on Barrow Island.

props.synopsis: Amid the spinifex on a remote Western Australian island looms Chevron's troubled carbon capture facility. The role the technology might play in cutting greenhouse gas emissions is likely to get a fresh airing at global climate talks in Azerbaijan.

title.children: A dangerous distraction or climate solution? Why world leaders pin their hopes on Chevron’s struggling carbon capture plant

image.altText: A small boy with his left arm in a bandage is treated by a medical worker in a head scarf.

props.synopsis: The Kamal Adwan hospital is struggling to remain operating after a major attack by the IDF, which claimed Hamas militants were sheltering in the facility.

title.children: When IDF soldiers surrounded this Gaza hospital, witnesses say snipers tossed coins to lure out children

image.altText: Sydney web developer Indra Arifin stands at a light rail stop in sydney wearing glasses and looking at the camera

props.synopsis: A QR code poster on the inside of a tram door is the only indication that commuters are opting-in to a data collection trial via their mobile phones. It's stopped one passenger from catching the light rail entirely.

title.children: How commuters are handing over their data to Sydney light rail services as soon as they step on the tram

image.altText: Piles of giant logs lying next to a forest of Australian native trees.

props.synopsis: Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek's struggling reforms have been offered a last-minute reprieve, provided she scraps an exemption for native logging.

title.children: Greens postpone demand for 'climate trigger' in eleventh-hour olive branch on environmental laws

image.altText: mid shot of man wearing glasses and suit with plane in background

props.synopsis: Both parties are in pre-election mode: clearing barnacles and ridding themselves of potential baggage that could weigh down their campaigns.

title.children: Killing season is here, but the leaders have something else on their minds

image.altText: An image taken from the exterior of a group of staff sitting around a board table .

props.synopsis: Despite flexible work being a popular choice for employees, a recent survey of CEOs shows 83 per cent want their workforce back in the office full time within three years.

title.children: CEOs want workers back in the office. How much longer will working from home be realistic?

image.altText: A man on a bike amongst rice paddies.

props.synopsis: This boss now wants to get on a four-day work week himself after seeing how happy and productive his staff are after he implemented it for them.

title.children: Staff happier and more productive after law firm ditches traditional work week

image.altText: A bush fire.

props.synopsis: Victoria's Country Fire Authority fears a bushfire in the Wimmera which destroyed at least one home over the weekend could burn for weeks.

title.children: Bushfire in Victoria's west could burn for some time after destroying properties over the weekend

image.altText: Tom Wright runs with the ball

props.synopsis: The Wallabies have hammered Wales 52-20, avenging their Rugby World Cup defeat 13 months prior and plunging the proud rugby nation into further chaos.

title.children: Wallabies hammer woeful Wales in Cardiff despite second-half red card

image.altText: Illuminated logos of Coles and Woolworths outside of each supermarket in a shopping centre.

props.synopsis: Woolworths's bosses will face the ACCC's inquiry into supermarket pricing today, as the consumer watchdog continues to prosecute its case that the corporate giant and its competitor Coles have been dudding their customers on discounts.

title.children: An ACCC inquiry has been quietly unpicking Australia's supermarkets. Now, one of the big two is fronting up

image.altText: A street litted with storm debris including a tin roof.

props.synopsis: Three commercial buildings in the same tiny town were destroyed after wild storms smashed much of NSW yesterday. A major clean-up is underway and more storms are forecast for the state's north today.

title.children: NSW town loses pub, pizza shop and general store in wild storm

image.altText: A comic-style image of two women, with a busy medical scene in the background, slightly faded.

props.synopsis: A young woman presented at a Melbourne hospital following an alleged needle spiking at a nightclub but wasn't able to get any tests to help her prove it. Here's why.

title.children: A young woman believes she was spiked at a nightclub. At hospital, there wasn’t a test to help her prove it

image.altText: A small child laying in a hospital bed with bandages on her hands.

props.synopsis: The study will test spider venom molecules against brain tissue made from the blood of individual epilepsy patients.

title.children: Tarantula venom study could help epilepsy patients like this toddler who's had 50 ambulance rides before her third birthday

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX 200 is poised to drop 0.3 per cent after Wall Street tumbled on profit taking and growing fears that inflation may return and scuttle deep rate cuts. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to fall after Wall Street slumps on inflation fears

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASIC on NAB's alleged credit breaches
ASIC suing NAB  over credit law breaches
ASX set to sag as Wall Street retreats

image.altText: Jannik Sinner celebrates with the trophy after winning the ATP Finals

props.synopsis: World number one Jannik Sinner has beaten Taylor Fritz to win the ATP Finals crown, adding another big title while his doping case is still pending.

title.children: Jannik Sinner claims ATP Finals crown, with doping case still pending

image.altText: A bench under a tree in a city park, with buildings and traffic lights in the background.

props.synopsis: The number of Australians 'at risk' of homelessness has increased more than 60 per cent since 2016, a new report says.

title.children: Three million Australians are at risk of homelessness and services say they're turning new clients away

props.synopsis: The National Archive of Australia has digitised over a million service records from World War II, many of which haven't been seen for 80 years.

title.children: Merle was one of many who served in WWII. Aged 104, she's seeing her records for the first time

image.altText: Albanese walking alone

props.synopsis: The government is bracing for the last parliamentary session of the year, and perhaps the term, with dozens of key policies unresolved.

title.children: Everything must go: As parliament resumes, it's crunch time for the Albanese agenda

image.altText: Zak Lomax points to the sky

props.synopsis: The NRL will take women's State of Origin to Sydney's second biggest rugby league stadium in 2025, while Queensland will host the opener of the men's series.

title.children: Men's State of Origin to open in Queensland as women set for grand stage finale

image.altText: Kim Birrell looks down

props.synopsis: Australia's hopes of ending a 50-year Billie Jean King Cup title drought have ended with a 2-0 quarter-final loss to inspired underdogs Slovakia in Spain.

title.children: Australia crashes out of Billie Jean King contention with Slovakia defeat

image.altText: A woman dressed as a nun holds a gun in her extended right hand.

props.synopsis: The echoes and ruptures of The Troubles still reverberate through Northern Ireland, and this faithful adaptation honours the complexities, nuances and contradictions of a state in crisis.

title.children: Dolours was 21 when she joined the IRA. This compelling new series tells her dark and violent story

image.altText: A man gives the thumbs down next to tents

props.synopsis: Brisbane City Council has teamed up with police to investigate "anti-social behaviour" at the city's homeless camps after an increasing number of complaints.

title.children: Concerns about parks 'becoming no-go zones' spark crack down on homeless camps

image.altText: Matilda Scholz celebrates after Port Adelaide's semifinal victory over Hawthorn 2024

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide going from 15th to a preliminary is more than just a feel good story. It's shows the growing competitive range of AFLW.

title.children: Port Adelaide's stunning rise shows the AFLW's increased competitiveness

image.altText: a red car with no roof, two people wearing pink in it adorned in rainbow flags.

props.synopsis: Pride and queer festivals in regional areas face an uncertain future as major sponsors withdraw financial support.

title.children: Queer festivals plead for help as major sponsors pull out

image.altText: A staged image of two gladiators fighting in the middle of the Colosseum at night time. The arena is dimly lit by fire.

props.synopsis: The short-term rentals company is promising armour and sword fights at the ancient arena to a chosen few, but Rome's councillor for culture and local housing activists have criticised the plan.

title.children: Airbnb's plan to host 'gladiator' battles at Rome's Colosseum causes outrage
